docs.lead_paragraph: Wendy Wasserstein spoke for a generation of driven but unsatisfied women in popular plays that included "The Heidi Chronicles."

headline.main: Wendy Wasserstein Dies at 55; Her Plays Spoke to a Generation

docs.lead_paragraph: Repeated lapses over many months by caseworkers at the city's child welfare agency created a chain of missed opportunities to save Nixzmary Brown, culminating in a canceled plan to visit her home the night she was killed, agency officials said yesterday. A preliminary review released by the city's Administration for Children's Services gave the most detailed account of the case to date, and it found that police officers played a role in deciding against conducting an emergency intervention at a crucial juncture in December: when a guidance counselor reported that the girl, already emaciated, had returned to school with a black eye after a prolonged absence.

headline.main: Caseworkers Missed Chances to Save Nixzmary, Report Says

docs.abstract: New York City Administration for Children's Services releases report reviewing case of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown, who had suffered longtime abuse and was killed on Jan 11 by stepfather Cesar Rodriguez; report reveals lost opportunities for intervention; report is released as child welfare Commissioner John B Mattingly appears before City Council to answer questions about agency procedures and handling of case; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Repeated lapses over many months by caseworkers at the city's child welfare agency created a chain of missed opportunities to save Nixzmary Brown, agency officials said.

byline.original: By JIM RUTENBERG and MIKE McINTIRE

docs.lead_paragraph: In last summer's prize-winning R-rated film ''Me and You and Everyone We Know,'' a barely pubescent boy is seduced into oral sex by two girls perhaps a year older, and his 6-year-old brother logs on to a pornographic chat room and solicits a grown woman with instant messages about ''poop.'' Is this what your teenage children are watching? If so, what message are they getting about sexual mores, and what effect will it have on their behavior?

headline.main: Children, Media and Sex: A Big Book of Blank Pages

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses how media-rich environment shapes children's views about sex; research suggests that children who view more television with sexual content behave as though they are 9 to 17 months older than they actually are; photo; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: What message are children getting about sexual mores, and what effect will it have on their behavior?

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Baby deliveries are in sync with the moon. THE FACTS -- Is there any link between childbirth and the lunar cycle? Many ancient cultures looked upon the moon as a sign of fertility, and since Roman times people have blamed full moons for all sorts of human behaviors, hence the word lunacy, from the Latin word for moon. But as mysterious and alluring as the link between full moons and births may sound, scientific studies suggest that it is more romance than reality.
docs.abstract: Research does not find any link between workloads in maternity wards and full moons; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Many ancient cultures looked upon the moon as a sign of fertility.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lunar New Year THURSDAY -- A dinner celebrating the Lunar New Year at Pier 60, Chelsea Piers, will raise money for the free legal services and civil rights advocacy of the Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins will present an award to Charles J. Ogletree Jr., a Harvard law professor, who will be among those honored. Cocktails at 6. Tickets, $600, from (212) 966-5932. Preserving Electronic Media THURSDAY -- Tom Brokaw will be the host of a black-tie dinner honoring Bob Wright, the chairman and chief executive of NBC Universal, and the cast and creative team of ''Saturday Night Live'' at the Waldorf-Astoria to aid the Museum of Television and Radio, which has spaces in both New York and Los Angeles. The proceeds of the evening will support the museum's preservation efforts, its education classes for schoolchildren and its special public programs. Cocktails begin at 6:30. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 621-6753. For Public Service THURSDAY -- Andrew Cuomo will speak at a cocktail party at Cipriani 23d Street, 200 Fifth Avenue, to support the Partnership for Public Service, a nonpartisan organization that encourages careers in the government for the nation's most talented college graduates. The evening begins at 7:30 with cocktails and a buffet dinner. Tickets, $125, from (212) 938-1032. Daytime Stars on 42nd St. FEB. 6 -- Members of the casts of ''All My Children,'' ''General Hospital,'' ''The View'' and ''One Life to Live'' will perform at the New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42d Street, to raise money for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS and the social service programs it supports for people with H.I.V. or AIDS. The show begins at 7:30. Tickets, $60, from (212) 840-0770, ext. 268. Support for Citizens FEB. 6 -- Tom Brokaw will be among those honored at a black-tie dinner and dance at the Waldorf-Astoria to raise money for the Citizens for NYC and the volunteer community and neighborhood groups it supports. Cocktails begin at 6:30, with music by Peter Duchin and his orchestra. Tickets, $750, from 212 989-0909, ext. 554. Orchid Dinner FEB. 7 -- A dinner-dance at the Rainbow Room will raise money for the New York Botanical Garden and the research it conducts on the evolution and genetics of orchids. Drinks begin at 7:30. Tickets, $1,000, from (718) 817-8773. For Inwood House FEB. 9 -- A preview of the Photography Show 2006 at the Seventh Regiment Armory will aid Inwood House, which provides teen pregnancy prevention programs, support services for young families and youth development. Cocktails and hors d'oeuvres will be served throughout the evening, which begins at 6. Tickets, $50, from (212) 861-4400, ext. 232. E-mail: society@nytimes.com Information: (212) 556-1141

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Dollars and Sense,'' by David Brooks (column, Jan. 26): I agree that Americans are more concerned about social threats like divorce, teenage pregnancy and poor early childhood education than economic threats like globalization, outsourcing and corporate power. What I fail to understand -- and get no insight on from Mr. Brooks's column -- is why a majority of Americans also seem disinclined to invest tax dollars in programs aimed at helping people avoid these social ills.
docs.abstract: Bill Zahren letter responds to David Brooks Jan 26 Op-Ed column; agrees that Americans are more concerned about social threats than economic threats; holds that conservatives ride to power by raising social fears, and then offer no solutions to problems

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is risky to be a baby in America. Figures released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention last year show that children under the age of 4 account for 78 percent of the deaths that stem from child abuse; and infants under the age of 1 sustain nearly half of those deaths.
